newsitem.title: UK: TENNIS SPOTLIGHT-WILLIAMS MEETS HER MATCH IN GRZYBOWSKA.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS SPOTLIGHT-WILLIAMS MEETS HER MATCH IN GRZYBOWSKA.

text.p: Venus Williams made her eagerly-awaited debut at Wimbledon on Saturday after five days of rain delays -- and promptly lost in the first round.
In keeping with her name, the American teenager is being touted as the rising star of women's tennis but she met her match in Poland's 18-year-old Magdalena Grzybowska.
Williams's weapons are her height -- 1.86 metres -- her power and her intelligent all-court game. Unluckily for her, Grzybowska possesses exactly the same attributes.
Grzybowska, ranked 91 in the world to Williams's 59, won the match 4-6 6-2 6-4 in one hour 49 minutes.
But Williams, who had covered her braided hair with beads in Wimbledon's purple and green colours for the occasion, was not down-hearted.
"I'm not too disappointed," the 17-year-old said. "It's my first Wimbledon and there will be many more to come."
Williams looked likely to make hard work of the tie from the start, hitting the first of 11 double faults to cede the first point of her opening service game.

Beads clattering in the cold air on Court One, Williams fought off two breakpoints to hold for 3-3 and then broke Grzybowska in the next game. The Pole, in her turn, contributed a double fault on breakpoint.
Williams had played only one previous tournament on grass -- last week's Eastbourne event -- but despite her lack of experience on the surface she was not afraid to come to the net.
She wrapped up the first set in 38 minutes with a service winner on her third set point.
Grzybowska, perhaps down-hearted by her lost opportunities in the opening set, hit three double faults at the start of the second to help the American to a 1-0 lead.
Williams saved two breakpoints, one with an ace, in the next game which saw some excellent volleying at the net by both women.
But Grzybowska got a break in the fourth game to draw level, fended off four breakpoints to hold in the next game and then broke again with a pass at the net to go 4-2 up.
She won the next game to love, finishing with the flourish of an ace, and took advantage of several forehand errors by Williams to win the set.
Williams continued to have trouble with the accuracy of her shots in the third set and found that luck was not on her side either.

At breakpoint up in the third game she slipped over and Grzybowska passed her. In the eighth game she double faulted, unaware that she was serving with a broken string until umpire Tony Little pointed it out.
As the set drew to a close, Williams grew impatient. She barely sat down at changeovers and was always out pacing the baseline well before Grzybowska had left her chair.
Grzybowska kept her head and calmly broke Williams to love in her final two service games to go through to Wimbledon's second round for the first time in her career.
